info.title: Signum Node API
info.description: This is the API documentation of the Signum Node

post.description:
Adds commitment to improve mining power. The commitment will be blocked, but never leave your account.
Read more about mining on the [official Signum Site](https://signum.network/mining) and on the [community wiki](https://signum.community/signum-mining/#commitment).
See also [removeCommitment](#get-/api-requestType-removeCommitment)

Remove commitment. The commitment gets unblocked, and will be available for free use. Removing commitment is only possible after 1440 blocks after last mined block.
Read more about mining on the [official Signum Site](https://signum.network/mining) and on the [community wiki](https://signum.community/signum-mining/#commitment).
See also [addCommitment](#get-/api-requestType-addCommitment)

Sets another account to receive your mining reward. This feature is necessary when you want mine in a pool. The recipient is the address of the pool.
Read more about mining on the [official Signum Site](https://signum.network/mining) and on the [community wiki](https://signum.community/signum-mining)
Sends Signa to another account. This is the most basic send operation and sends a single amount to another account. Of course, you can attach additional message or data to this transactions.
Sends different amounts of Signa to up to 64 recipients. As this operation occupies the attachment section no further attachments, like messages are possible

parameters.name: recipients
parameters.description: A list of (numericIds:amountNQT)-tuples. You can have at maximum 64 entries. __Attention: Duplicated addresses make this transaction fail__

post.description: Sends the same amount of Signa to up to 128 account. As this operation occupies the attachment section no further attachments, like messages are possible

parameters.name: recipients
parameters.description: A list of account Ids. You can have at maximum 128 entries. __Attention: Duplicated addresses make this transaction fail__

post.description: Sends Signa to another account at recurring frequency. See also [Cancel Subscription](#post-/api-requestType-subscriptionCancel)

parameters.name: frequency
parameters.description: The frequency of the payment in seconds, e.g. per day is 86400 seconds, per month is 2592000 seconds. If no balance is available the subscription halts.

post.description:
Sends a plain or P2P encrypted message to another account. The message can be either a textual message or binary data in form of a hexadecimal string.
In contrast to [Send Signa](#post-/api-requestType-sendMoney) you don't have to send any amount, but the fee only. The fee depends on the amount of characters you send, and can be between 0.01 and 0.06 Signa.
Cancels a running subscription. See also [Create Subscription](#post-/api-requestType-sendMoneySubscription)

parameters.name: subscription
parameters.description: The subscription identifier. See [getAccountSubscriptions]()

post.description: Add or edit your accounts name and description.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Set an arbitrary name for your account. This will show up in diverse tools of the ecosystem. This name is not unique!

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: Set an arbitrary description.

post.description:
Signs a transaction, which can be [broadcast](#post-/api-requestType-broadcastTransaction) to the network then. This is merely a low-level API endpoint.
To get an _unsigned_ transaction object you use your public key to post transactions instead of your passphrase.

parameters.name: unsignedTransactionBytes
parameters.description: The _unsigned_ transaction bytes in hexadecimal representation.

parameters.name: unsignedTransactionJSON
parameters.description: The _unsigned_ transaction and _stringified_ JSON object. It's recommended to use the `unsignedTransactionBytes` instead.

200.description: Signed Transaction Response. Use the returned `transactionBytes` with [broadcastTransaction](#post-/api-requestType-broadcastTransaction)

verify.description: Indicates whether the transaction could be verified or not.

post.description: Sends a _signed_ transaction to the network. This is merely a low-level API endpoint

parameters.name: transactionBytes
parameters.description: The _signed_ transaction bytes in hexadecimal representation

parameters.name: transactionTransactionJSON
parameters.description: The _signed_ transaction and _stringified_ JSON object. It's recommended to use the `transactionBytes` instead.

post.description: Parses a _signed_ and/or _unsigned_ transaction bytes and returns as JSON object. This is merely a low-level API endpoint.

parameters.name: transactionBytes
parameters.description: The _signed_ and/or _unsigned_ transaction bytes in hexadecimal representation.

200.description: The parsed JSON object of the transaction

post.description: This allows you to dump the database in a file. __Attention: This is a very long running operation__

parameters.name: filename
parameters.description: The name of the resulting file

post.description: This allows to remove up to 1440 most recent transactions in the nodes database. Use this to get your database in sync with network when you are on a fork. __Attention: This operation can take some minutes__

parameters.name: numBlocks
parameters.description: The amount of blocks to be removed

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The block height to which it should be reset. Only block heights which are at maximum 1440 blocks in the past

post.description: Prunes unconfirmed transactions.
Resets the node and forces a resync.

Issues a new token. Tokens can be issued as _mintable_ that is they have no fixed supply and the supply can be [increased by the creator](#post-/api-requestType-mintAsset) of this token
Mind, that issuing a token has [elevated fees involved](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-31.md#specification), i.e. 150 Signa.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The tokens name and also its ticker symbol. You can only use up to ten alphanumeric characters and no special chars

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: Any arbitrary description up to 1000 characters length.

parameters.name: decimals
parameters.description:
The number of decimals for this token.
If you issue a token with 2 decimals, then it can be fractioned in per hundreds, i.e. 0.01. To have an integral token you need to consider the decimals. So, one token is a quantity of 100

parameters.name: mintable
parameters.description: Set the token mintable, i.e. allow a dynamic supply (potentially inflationary), or define a fixed supply (deflationary)

post.description: Adds more supply to a token (called minting). The fees for minting are as low as for any common transaction. To burn tokens simply [send tokens](#post-/api-requestType-transferAsset) to the Burn Address `0` (`S-2222-2222-2222-22222`)

Adds/Marks an account as treasury account.When marking an account as treasury account, the accounts token balance will not be considered for circulating supply and is also not eligible for token distribution.
This operation is not revertible!
See also [the specification](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-33.md#define-treasury-accounts)

parameters.name: recipient
parameters.description: The accounts address that should be marked as treasury account.

parameters.name: referencedTransactionFullHash
parameters.description:
Use this field to reference to the tokens issue transaction hash. This is the way to link to the asset!
Mind, that Smart Contracts cannot be marked as treasury accounts and only the creator can mark accounts as treasury accounts.

post.description:
This function distributes Signa __and/or__ Tokens to token holders (excluding treasury accounts).

This method efficiently runs a proportional distribution to token holders at a speed of approx. 1.2M payouts per block.
See also [the specification](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-33.md#payment-to-token-holders)

parameters.name: quantityMinimumQNT
parameters.description: The minimum quantity of tokens a holder needs to be eligible for distribution

parameters.name: amountNQT
parameters.description:
The _total_ amount in Signa to be distributed to the token holders.
Once distributed, you can get the individual payout per account using [Get Distribution Amount](#post-/api-requestType-distributeToAssetHolders)

parameters.name: assetToDistribute
parameters.description:
The token that shall be distributed.
Mind that it's possible to distribute either a token, Signa, or both together.

parameters.name: quantityQNT
parameters.description: The _total_ quantity of the token (from `assetToDistribute`) to be distributed

parameters.name: feeNQT
parameters.description:
To distribute tokens to holder a special fee [calculation applies](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-33.md#payment-to-token-holders), i.e. `0.01 + (0.001 * number of eligble recipients)` Signa.
To calculate the fee you may use [Get Token](#get-/api-requestType-getAsset) with your minimum and use `numberOfAccounts` from the response.

post.description: Transfer token quantities to another account. To burn a token simply [send tokens](#post-/api-requestType-transferAsset) to the Burn Address `0` (`S-2222-2222-2222-22222`)
Transfer multiple tokens to another account.

parameters.name: assetIds
parameters.description: A list of up to 4 token identifiers, separated by `;`

parameters.name: quantitiesQNT
parameters.description: A list of up to 4 quantities according the order of the `assetIds`, , separated by `;`

post.description: Places an Ask Order (as an intent to __sell__ a token) for a specific token on the native on-chain token exchange. See also [Cancel Ask Order]() or [getAskOrders]()
Cancels a pending Ask Order. See also [Place Ask Order]() or [getAskOrders]()
Places an Bid Order (as an intent to __buy__ a token) for a specific token on the native on-chain token exchange. See also [Cancel Bid Order]() or [getBidOrders]()
Cancels a pending Bid Order. See also [Place Bid Order]() or [getBidOrders]()

Create or edit an alias. An alias allows to have __mutable__ content (up to 1000 chars), i.e. you can use this as an on-chain Name Service, or other interesting things. Additionally, it's possible to trade aliases!

parameters.name: aliasName
parameters.description: If not exists already, you create an alias with the given __unique__ name. If you are the owner of the alias, then you can update the content. - Like a database _upsert_ operation.

parameters.name: aliasURI
parameters.description:
Sets/Updates the arbitrary _content_ of this alias.
Historically, the alias system was considered for Name Service operations only, that's why it is called URI.
The legacy format for account aliases is `acct:@burst`. You may check for that format for legacy account aliases

post.description: Sets an alias for sale. Once on sale others can [buy the alias](#post-/api-requestType-buyAlias).

parameters.name: aliasName
parameters.description: Instead of `alias` you can use the alias' name also.

parameters.name: recipient
parameters.description: You can specify a single buyer. This buyer will get a notification, that you are willing to sell this alias exclusively to him/her. Otherwise, your alias can be bought by everyone

parameters.name: priceNQT
parameters.description: The amount you want for the alias.

post.description: Buy an alias that is [on sale](#post-/api-requestType-sellAlias).

parameters.name: aliasName
parameters.description: Instead of `alias` you can use the alias' name also.

parameters.name: recipient
parameters.description: You can specify a single buyer. This buyer will get a notification, that you are willing to sell this alias exclusively to him/her. Otherwise, your alias can be bought by everyone

parameters.name: amountNQT
parameters.description: The amount you want to pay for the alias, but must be at least the minimum price asked for.

post.description: Submits a nonce trying to validate a block. This is _the_ endpoint for (solo) miners

parameters.name: blockheight
parameters.description: The block height for the submitted nonce.

parameters.name: nonce
parameters.description: The nonce

parameters.name: accountId
parameters.description: Instead of sending the passphrase you can send the accountId. The account id must be allowed in the configuration of the node.

result.description: "success" in case of successful submission, otherwise a detailed message of what went wrong

errorCode.description: The calculated deadline for the submission

post.description:
Publishes/Deploys a Smart Contract.
Read more about smart contracts on the [official Signum Site](https://signum.network/smartcontracts) and on the [community wiki](https://signum.community/signum-smart-contracts/).
See also [SmartC](https://github.com/deleterium/SmartC/tree/stable/docs) and [SmartJ](https://github.com/signum-network/signum-smartj)

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the contract. At maximum 30 alphanumerical characters without special chars and whitespaces

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: This can be any arbitrary textual, json or even binary description. The maximum limit is 1000 characters, either text or binary (in hex form)

parameters.name: code
parameters.description: The compiled byte code sequence of the code. This code is being created with SmartC or either SmartJ

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: This is the initial data stack. With this field it's possible to initialize a contracts variables

parameters.name: dpages
parameters.description: Number of pages of the data stack. Each Page has a size of 256 bytes.

parameters.name: cspages
parameters.description: Number of pages of the code stack. Each Page has a size of 256 bytes.

parameters.name: uspages
parameters.description: Number of pages of the user stack. Each Page has a size of 256 bytes.

parameters.name: minActivationAmountNQT
parameters.description:
The minimum amount to dispatch the contracts execution expressed in Planck, i.e. 1 Signa = 10E8 Planck = 100000000 Planck.
This value should be chosen in a way, that the contract never runs out of balance.

parameters.name: referencedTransactionFullHash
parameters.description: Instead of sending the `code`, it's possible to reuse an existing code from a previously published contract. Just use that contracts full hash. This unique concept is called [Green Contract](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-30.md) and reduces the payload and contract creation costs.

get.description: Get account information, like balances, commitment and token balances of an account.

parameters.name: account
parameters.description: The account identifier

parameters.name: getCommittedAmount
parameters.description: Returns the entire commitment amount

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: When set this blockheight the accounts situation at the given height will be returned

parameters.name: estimateCommitment
parameters.description: If set `true` the estimated commitment per TiB will be returned

get.description: Get all account identifiers with a specific reward recipient, i.e. the accounts of a pool

parameters.name: account
parameters.description: The reward recipient, i.e. the pool address

200.description:
Account Id List response
A list with one (mostly self) or more accounts. If the only account in the list is identical to the passed parameter, then the given account has no reward recipient set.

get.description: Get the reward recipient of an account, i.e. check if an account joined a mining pool.

parameters.name: account
parameters.description: The account to be checked for

200.description: The account that gets the mining reward, i.e. a mining pools account address. If the responded account is identical to the input, then the account did not join a pool.

get.description: Gets the contracts a given account created.

parameters.name: machineCodeHashId
parameters.description:
This hash identifies a specific code. Using this parameter as additional filter to search only for a specific class of contracts, i.e. NFTSRC40.
See also the [green contract specification](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-30.md)

get.description: Gets a specific smart contract
Gets a specific contracts situation at a given moment in the past

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: When set this block height the contracts situation at the given height will be returned

get.description: Gets all smart contract ids. You can optionally filter by the machine code hash, to get only contracts of a specific type

parameters.name: machineCodeHashId
parameters.description:
This hash identifies a specific code. Using this parameter as additional filter to search only for a specific class of contracts, i.e. NFTSRC40.
See also the [green contract specification](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-30.md)

get.description:
Gets a value from a smart contract from its [data store](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-38.md).
Non existing keys result always in `0`(Zero)

parameters.name: key1
parameters.description: The 1st key of the map

parameters.name: key2
parameters.description: The 2nd key of the map

get.description: Get the tokens an account owns.

assetBalances.description: The total token balances (in _quantity_) which this account owns, including reserved ones

unconfirmedAssetBalances.description: The __available__ token balances (in _quantity_) which this account owns, excluding reserved ones

get.description:
Get the transaction data of a specific transaction.
Each Transaction may carry an additional attachment with a different structure. This structure depends on it's [`type` and `subtype`](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types)

parameters.name: fullHash
parameters.description: Alternatively, the transactions full hash can be used.

get.description: Get the information necessary for the miners.

height.description: The height of the current block to be forged

averageCommitmentNQT.description: The networks average commitment per TiB expressed in Planck

lastBlockReward.description: The last block reward in Signa.

lastBlockRewardNQT.description: The last block reward in Planck.

get.description:
Get all pending transactions or of a specific account.
Each Transaction may carry an additional attachment with a different structure. This structure depends on it's [`type` and `subtype`](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types)

parameters.name: account
parameters.description: When given, only pending transactions of this account are returned. If not, _all_ pending transactions of the network are returned

parameters.name: includeIndirect
parameters.description: When set true, multiple payment transactions are returned also. This option applies only when using `account`

get.description:
Get the paid amount per account of a mass distribution or multi out payments.

Due to the nature of how multiple payouts or distribution works, an accounts received payout does not appear in the common transaction amount field. The common transaction carries the total distributed/paid amount. So, one need this method to get the individually paid amount.

parameters.name: transaction
parameters.description: The id of a [distribution transaction](#post-/api-requestType-distributeToAssetHolders) or [multiple payout](#post-/api-requestType-sendMoneyMulti)

200.description:
Individual Payout Response.
__Note__: The response does not carry the related asset information. You need to pull this from the related `transaction`

height.description: The block height number of occurred payment.

get.description: This method may help to determine the minimum fee for the current block. See also the [fee policies](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-34.md)

200.description: Fee suggestions. The higher the fee the more prioritized its validation, i.e. chances are higher to make it into the next block.

get.description: Get this blockchains constant parameters
Get the information of this node/peer.
Get some basic information of the current blockchains status.

application.description: The configured name of the node, usually 'BRS'. But can be different for other chains/networks

time.description: The current time as a timestamp in seconds since block 0.

averageCommitmentNQT.description: The networks average commitment per TiB expressed in Planck

numberOfBlocks.description: The number of blocks including the current non-forged block

lastBlockchainFeeder.description: The public available name of the last node that communicated with this node

lastBlockchainFeederHeight.description: The last block height this nodes got from the feeder

isScanning.description: Indicates if this node is scanning/syncing

get.description: Get information about a specific Peer. See also [Get Node/Peer Id List]()

parameters.name: peer
parameters.description: The nodes IP. You can get it from [Get Connected Nodes/Peers]()

application.description: The configured name of the node, usually 'BRS'. But can be different for other chains/networks

platform.description: The platform name. Can be any name, but must be a receiver address for the [Signum Network Reward Program](https://signum.community/signum-snr-awards/)

state.description:
The state of the node,
  • 0 - Not Connected
  • 1 - Connected
  • 2 - Disconnected

announcedAddress.description: The announce address of this node, if public

shareAddress.description: Indicator if the address is shared publicly. This is relevant for the [Signum Network Reward Program](https://signum.community/signum-snr-awards/)

lastUpdated.description: The last know update in block timestamp, i.e. seconds since block 0 (Genesis Block)

blacklisted.description: Indicator if the node is blacklisted.

get.description: Get a list of known peers/nodes. See also [Get Node/Peer](#get-/api-requestType-getPeer)

parameters.name: active
parameters.description: Select whether active or inactive, i.e. `NON_CONNECTED` peers should be listed.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: Query peers by one of the states

get.description: Get the chains time stamp in seconds since Block 0

time.description: The time since beginning of the chain (Block 0)

get.description: Get a bunch of information about the current chains status. This method returns more information than [Get Blockchain Info](#get-/api-requestType-getBlockchainStatus)

parameters.name: includeCounts
parameters.description: Includes additional counts. This operation requires the `apiKey` and can take a significant amount of time.

application.description: The configured name of the node, usually 'BRS'. But can be different for other chains/networks

time.description: The current time as a timestamp in seconds since block 0.

totalMinedNQT.description: The total of mined coins in Planck (only available if `includeCounts` is true)

totalEffectiveBalance.description: The total supply of the network in Signa (only available if `includeCounts` is true)

totalEffectiveBalanceNQT.description: The total supply of the network in Planck (only available if `includeCounts` is true)

totalCommittedNQT.description: The total amount of commitment of the network in Planck (only available if `includeCounts` is true)

numberOfBlocks.description: The number of blocks including the current non-forged block

numberOfOrders.description: The number of token orders (bids and asks)

numberOfAskOrders.description: The number of ask token orders

numberOfBidOrders.description: The number of bid token orders

lastBlockchainFeeder.description: The public available name of the last node that communicated with this node

lastBlockchainFeederHeight.description: The last block height this nodes got from the feeder

isScanning.description: Indicates if this node is scanning/syncing

indirectIncomingServiceEnabled.description: Indicates if this node has `indirectIncoming` functionality (token distribution) enabled

availableProcessors.description: Number of processors of this node

maxMemory.description: Amount of maximum available memory of the node (in bytes)

totalMemory.description: Amount used memory of the node (in bytes)

freeMemory.description: Amount of free memory of the node (in bytes)

get.description: Get aliases of an account.

200.description: The list of aliases this account owns.

get.description: Get an alias by its id or unique name

parameters.name: alias
parameters.description: The alias Id

parameters.name: aliasName
parameters.description: The unique alias name

get.description: Get a specific block. Returns the last block if no argument is given.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The block height number (more commonly used)

parameters.name: includeTransactions
parameters.description: If set `true` the transaction objects will be returned, otherwise the transaction identifiers

get.description: Gets a range of blocks. Return the most recent 500 blocks if no argument is given

parameters.name: includeTransactions
parameters.description: If set `true` the transaction objects will be returned, otherwise the transaction identifiers

get.description: Gets the blocks an account forged.

parameters.name: includeTransactions
parameters.description: If set `true` the transaction objects will be returned, otherwise the transaction identifiers

get.description: Gets the blocks an account forged.
Gets the current ask orders of an account
Gets the current bid orders of an account
Gets all open ask orders
Gets all open bid orders
Get a single ask order
Get a range of ask orders from a token
Get a single bid order
Get a range of bid orders from a token
Get a token

parameters.name: quantityMinimumQNT
parameters.description: Count only accounts with given minimum quantity. This parameter affects for the `numberOfAccounts` in the response. This helps you to calculate the fees upfront for [Distribution to Token  holders](#post-/api-requestType-distributeToAssetHolders)

get.description: Get all tokens, but at maximum 500 per call.
Get token ids.
Get a list of token holder.

parameters.name: ignoreTreasury
parameters.description: If set `true`, [Treasury Accounts](#post-/api-requestType-addAssetTreasuryAccount) won't be returned. Default is false

parameters.name: quantityMinimumQNT
parameters.description: Returns only accounts with given minimum quantity.

get.description: Get all tokens an account issued
Get trades within a given range.

parameters.name: includeAssetInfo
parameters.description: If set `true` (default), the tokens `name` and `decimals` is included in the response

get.description: Get a list of token transfers.

parameters.name: asset
parameters.description: The related token identifier. You can use this alone or together with `account`

parameters.name: account
parameters.description: The account identifier. You can use this alone or together with `asset`

get.description: Get account public key. Useful to check if an account exists or is activated
Get accounts running subscriptions, i.e. recurring payments. These are outgoing subscriptions. See [incoming subscriptions](#get-/api-requestType-getSubscriptionsToAccount)
Get subscriptions sent to an account/recipient, incoming subscriptions. See [outgoing subscriptions](#get-/api-requestType-getAccountSubscriptions)
Get a subscription, i.e. recurring payment.

parameters.name: subscription
parameters.description: The identifier of a subscription, i.e. its initial transaction id

get.description:
Get all pending transaction identifiers or of a specific account.
Each Transaction may carry an additional attachment with a different structure. This structure depends on it's [`type` and `subtype`](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types)

parameters.name: account
parameters.description: When given, only pending transactions of this account are returned. If not, _all_ pending transactions of the network are returned

parameters.name: includeIndirect
parameters.description: When set true, multiple payment transactions are returned also. This option applies only when using `account`

get.description: Get account transactions

parameters.name: type
parameters.description:
The primary type of wanted transactions. This allows to filter by transaction types.
See [Transaction Types](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types) and or [Get Blockchain Parameters](#get-/api-requestType-getConstants)

parameters.name: subtype
parameters.description:
The secondary type of wanted transactions. This allows to filter by transaction types.
See [Transaction Types](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types) and or [Get Blockchain Parameters](#get-/api-requestType-getConstants)

parameters.name: numberOfConfirmation
parameters.description: The minimum number of confirmations for wanted transactions.

parameters.name: includeIndirect
parameters.description: When set true, multiple payment transactions are returned also.

schema.description:
A list of transactions.
__Note__: For performance/stability reasons a node returns at maximum 500 items. All transaction query methods offer `firstIndex` and `lastIndex` to paginate through the transaction.

get.description: Get account transaction identifiers.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description:
The primary type of wanted transactions. This allows to filter by transaction types.
See [Transaction Types](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types) and or [Get Blockchain Parameters](#get-/api-requestType-getConstants)

parameters.name: subtype
parameters.description:
The secondary type of wanted transactions. This allows to filter by transaction types.
See [Transaction Types](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types) and or [Get Blockchain Parameters](#get-/api-requestType-getConstants)

parameters.name: numberOfConfirmation
parameters.description: The minimum number of confirmations for wanted transactions.

parameters.name: includeIndirect
parameters.description: When set true, multiple payment transactions are returned also.

get.description: Get account identifiers by their name. See als [Set Account Information](#post-/api-requestType-setAccountInfo)

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the accounts

get.description: Get an accounts balance information.

balanceNQT.description: Your total balance, including commitment and reserved orders

unconfirmedBalanceNQT.description:
The currently available balance.
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

forgedBalanceNQT.description:
The balance forged by you (Solo-Mining only).
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

guaranteedBalanceNQT.description:
Your total balance, including commitment and reserved orders.
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

get.description: Get trades of a token end even for a given account.

parameters.name: asset
parameters.description: The related token identifier. You can use this alone or together with `account`

parameters.name: account
parameters.description: The account identifier. You can use this alone or together with `asset`

parameters.name: includeAssetInfo
parameters.description: If set `true` (default), the tokens `name` and `decimals` is included in the response

get.description: Get all aliases, which are on sale, i.e. can be bought.

balanceNQT.description: Your total balance, including commitment and reserved orders

unconfirmedBalanceNQT.description:
The currently available balance.
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

committedBalanceNQT.description:
Your committed balance.
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

forgedBalanceNQT.description:
The balance forged by you (Solo-Mining only).
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

guaranteedBalanceNQT.description:
Your total balance, including commitment and reserved orders.
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

commitmentNQT.description:
The current network commitment estimate per TiB.
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

accountRSExtended.description: The extended address carries the public key base36 encoded

name.description: The name of the account, if it was set with [Set Account Info](#post-/api-requestType-setAccountInfo)

description.description: The description of the account, if it was set with [Set Account Info](#post-/api-requestType-setAccountInfo)

assetBalances.description: The total token balances (in _quantity_) which this account owns, including reserved ones

unconfirmedAssetBalances.description: The __available__ token balances (in _quantity_) which this account owns, excluding reserved ones

address.description: The account identifier as numeric Id or Reed-Solomon encoded address, i.e. S-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXX

priceNQT.description: The price in Planck wanted for the alias.When an alias has this field is it available for buying, i.e. it is On Sale.

buyer.description: The potential buyer of this alias. When this field is given, only that account can buy the alias

amount.description: The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

decimals.description:
The number of decimals for this token.
If you issue a token with 2 decimals, then it can be fractioned in per hundreds, i.e. 0.01. To have an integral token you need to consider the decimals. So, one token is a quantity of 100

mintable.description: Set the token mintable, i.e. allow a dynamic supply (potentially inflationary), or define a fixed supply (deflationary)

quantityQNT.description: The total quantity (maximum supply) expressed as integral quantity e.g. the quantity=100 of a token with 2 decimals is expressed as 10000

quantityCirculatingQNT.description: The __circulating__ quantity expressed as integral quantity e.g. the quantity=100 of a token with 2 decimals is expressed as 10000

numberOfAccounts.description: Total number of accounts owning this token

example.name: TRESTC
example.description: Token issued and controlled by smart contract ID: 8703144722673801264

assetName.description: The name and symbol of this token. You can only use up to ten alphanumeric characters and no special chars

numberOfTransactions.description: Amount of transaction in this block

payloadLength.description: The total payload length of this block in bytes

contractAddress.description: The contracts address as Reed-Solomon encoded address, i.e. S-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXX

machineData.description: The current data stack of the contract in hexadecimal form. You can inspect the data using the [Contract Inspector](https://contracts-inspector.ohager.vercel.app/)

balanceNQT.description:
The contracts current balance.
Mind that contracts without balance do not run at all.
The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

nextBlock.description: The next block when this contract will be ready to run

frozen.description:
Indicates if a contract is stuck, i.e. due to insufficient balance.
Do not rely on that status. Once frozen, this status never gets rest to zero, although the contract is able to run.
Read about contract states also [here](https://github.com/deleterium/SmartC/blob/stable/docs/1-Basis.md#contract-states)

stopped.description:
Indicates if a contract stopped (by sleep or halt instruction) and waiting for continuation.
Read about contract states also [here](https://github.com/deleterium/SmartC/blob/stable/docs/1-Basis.md#contract-states)

finished.description:
Indicates that a contract finished entirely his current execution cycle.
Read about contract states also [here](https://github.com/deleterium/SmartC/blob/stable/docs/1-Basis.md#contract-states)

dead.description:
Indicates that a contract suffered a severe error and is lost.
Read about contract states also [here](https://github.com/deleterium/SmartC/blob/stable/docs/1-Basis.md#contract-states)

machineCodeHashId.description: The hash id for the contracts code. So, we can identify different instances of the same contract code by this identifier.

minActivation.description: The amount needed to activate an execution of the contract, i.e.is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

creationBlock.description: The block when this contract was created.

hash.description: A hexadecimal string of fixed size representing 256 Bit Hashes (SHA-256)

hexString.description: A hexadecimal string of arbitrary length

numericId.description: The account identifier as numeric Id

quantity.description: The quantity is a tokens amount. It depends on the decimals a token supports, e.g. the quantity=100 of a token with 2 decimals is expressed as 10000

rsAddress.description: The account identifier as Reed-Solomon encoded address, i.e. S-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXX

transactionBytes.description: The binary representation of the entire transaction. This can be parsed with (parseTransactionBytes)[#post-/api-requestType-parseTransaction]

unsignedTransactionBytes.description: The binary representation of the entire _unsigned_ transaction. This can be parsed with (parseTransactionBytes)[#post-/api-requestType-parseTransaction]

frequency.description: The frequency of the payment in seconds, e.g. per day is 86400 seconds, per month is 2592000 seconds. If no balance is available the subscription halts.

timeNext.description: The timestamp of the next payment.

timestamp.description: The time in seconds since first Block (Genesis) of the chain.

priceNQT.description: The price __per integral token__, i.e. if a token has 2 (two) decimals, then this amount is per 100 QNT (Quantity). The amount is always returned in Planck, that is Signa multiplied by 10E8

askOrder.description: The transaction identifier for the related ask order

bidOrder.description: The transaction identifier for the related bid order

askOrderHeight.description: The block height of the ask order

decimals.description:
The number of decimals for this token.
If you issue a token with 2 decimals, then it can be fractioned in per hundreds, i.e. 0.01. To have an integral token you need to consider the decimals. So, one token is a quantity of 100

type.description: The transaction type. See also [getConstants]() and [here](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types)

subtype.description: The transaction subtype. See also [getConstants]() and [here](https://docs.signum.network/signum/transaction-types)

attachment.description: This is an arbitrary object carrying additional data, which depends mostly on the transaction type. It has no fixed structure. It always comes with a `version.<type>` field.

version.description: The version number of this structure

cashBackId.description:
The Account Id where part of the fees is being paid to.
Read more about cashback [here](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-35.md)

block.description: The block Id of the transaction. This field is only available on forged/accepted transactions.

unsignedTransactionBytes.description: The binary representation of the entire _unsigned_ transaction. This can be parsed with (parseTransactionBytes)[#post-/api-requestType-parseTransaction]

quantityQNT.name: quantityQNT
quantityQNT.description: The quantity of tokens expressed as an integer value, considering the number of decimals of the related token. If a token has two decimals the quantity value for 100 token is 10000.

apiKey.name: apiKey
apiKey.description:
Any arbitrary string.
🔓 __Security Advice: Use a very strong and truly random key, or even disable admin operation entirely in your node config. Exposing admin operations is a security risk.__

amountNQT.name: amountNQT
amountNQT.description: The amount expressed in Planck, i.e. 1 Signa = 10E8 Planck = 100000000 Planck

feeNQT.name: feeNQT
feeNQT.description:
The fee for this transaction expressed in Planck, i.e. 0.01 Signa = 0.01 * 10E8 Planck = 1000000 Planck - The fee depends on the transaction type, but minimum fee is 0.01 Signa
Read more about the fees [here](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-34.md)

secretPhrase.name: secretPhrase
secretPhrase.description:
_Your_ secret passphrase.
🔓 __Security Advice: It's not recommended to pass this parameter to remote nodes unless you trust the node operator.__

publicKey.name: publicKey
publicKey.description:
The public key of the sending account.
If you send this key instead of the `secretPhrase`, you get the _unsigned_ transaction back, which can then be signed locally. In that case the transaction is not being published.

deadline.name: deadline
deadline.description: The deadline for how long the transaction may stay in the nodes mempool expressed in minutes until the transaction is being discarded

broadcast.name: broadcast
broadcast.description: If set `false` the transaction will not be broadcast to the network

recipient.name: recipient
recipient.description: The recipients address. If the recipients address is `0` or `S-2222-2222-2222-22222` then you burn the tokens or coins sent to it.

recipientPublicKey.name: recipientPublicKey
recipientPublicKey.description: If you send a the recipients public key with a transaction you can automatically register (and activate) an account within the blockchain.

referencedTransactionFullHash.name: referencedTransactionFullHash
referencedTransactionFullHash.description: Using this field allows to make a transaction dependent on other transactions. This field will also be used for referencing carbon contracts

message.name: message
message.description: It's possible to attach arbitrary data (in form of messages) to a transaction. The maximum limit is 1000 characters, either text or binary (in hex form)

messageIsText.name: messageIsText
messageIsText.description: Determines if the attached `message` is either text or binary data (hexadecimal string)

messageToEncrypt.name: messageToEncrypt
messageToEncrypt.description:
It's possible to attach P2P encrypted arbitrary data (in form of messages) to a transaction. The maximum limit is 1000 characters, either text or binary (in hex form).
When using P2P encryption you need to pass `recipientPublicKey` also.
🔓 __Security Advice: When you use this you are sending the message in plain text to the node.__

messageToEncryptIsText.name: messageToEncryptIsText
messageToEncryptIsText.description: Determines if the attached `messageToEncrypt` is either text or binary data (hexadecimal string)

encryptedMessageData.name: encryptedMessageData
encryptedMessageData.description: It's possible to encrypt the data locally and send the encrypted data for maximum security. Together with this field you need to send `encryptedMessageNonce` also.

encryptedMessageNonce.name: encryptedMessageNonce
encryptedMessageNonce.description: It's possible to encrypt the data locally and send the encrypted data for maximum security. Together with this field you need to send `encryptedMessageData` also.

messageToEncryptToSelf.name: messageToEncryptToSelf
messageToEncryptToSelf.description: When encrypting messages to yourself, you may want to use this field.

messageToEncryptToSelfIsText.name: messageToEncryptToSelfIsText
messageToEncryptToSelfIsText.description: Determines if the attached `messageToEncryptToSelf` is either text or binary data (hexadecimal string)

encryptToSelfMessageData.name: encryptToSelfMessageData
encryptToSelfMessageData.description: It's possible to encrypt the data locally and send the encrypted data for maximum security. Together with this field you need to send `encryptToSelfMessageNonce` also.

encryptToSelfMessageNonce.name: encryptToSelfMessageNonce
encryptToSelfMessageNonce.description: It's possible to encrypt the data locally and send the encrypted data for maximum security. Together with this field you need to send `encryptToSelfMessageData` also.

timestamp.name: timestamp
timestamp.description: The timestamp from which should be searched. Use this to get items only since that time. The time in seconds since first Block (Genesis) of the chain.

firstIndex.name: firstIndex
firstIndex.description: The first index to be returned. Use this for pagination.

lastIndex.name: lastIndex
lastIndex.description: The last index to be returned. Use this for pagination. If not set, at maximum 500 items beginning at `firstIndex` will be returned

constants.description: The constants of this blockchain chain instance - This information are the constant attributes of this blockchain

error.description: Error Response - __IMPORTANT: Error Responses always come with a HTTP Status Code 200 🤷__

errorDescription.description: The error message indicating what the issue is

schema.description:
A list of transactions.
__Note__: For performance/stability reasons a node returns at maximum 500 items. All transaction query methods offer `firstIndex` and `lastIndex` to paginate through the transaction.

tags.name: payment
tags.description:
Functions which are related to value transfers of the base currency "Signa"

The platform offers different types of payments:
  • Single Payments (with attached messages)
  • Multiple Payments within a single transaction
  • Recurring Payments a la Subscriptions

tags.name: token
tags.description:
All operations related to Tokens and Tokenomics.

The native fungible token engine is very versatile offering the following features:
  • On-chain Decentralized Exchange
  • Mintable/Burnable Tokens
  • Single or Multiple Token Transfer within a single transaction
  • Ultra-Fast Distributions to Token Holders (up to 1.2M holders per block)

tags.name: contract
tags.description:
All operations related to Smart Contracts.

Signum was the first public block chain that introduced [turing complete](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turing_completeness) fully programmable Smart Contracts.

The engine comes with some very outstanding features, like
  • Write contracts in [Java](https://github.com/signum-network/signum-smartj)- or [C](https://github.com/deleterium/SmartC/tree/stable/docs)-like Syntax
  • Re-usable code aka [Green Contracts](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-30.md)
  • Self-executing contracts (no external trigger, i.e. transaction required)
  • [Full Token Support](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-39.md)
  • Dynamic Data Storage in form of [Key-Value-Maps](https://github.com/signum-network/SIPs/blob/master/SIP/sip-38.md)

Read more about smart contracts on the [official Signum Site](https://signum.network/smartcontracts) and on the [community wiki](https://signum.community/signum-smart-contracts/).

tags.name: network
tags.description: All network, blockchain and or node related operations

tags.name: alias
tags.description:
All Alias related operations.

The Alias feature allows to assign __mutable__ content to a fixed identifier. This makes it possible to have something like a Account Name Service (ANS) or other interesting use cases. It gets even more interesting, because Aliases are tradeable.

tags.name: mining
tags.description: All mining related methods. Leran more about mining [here](https://signum.network/mining) and also in the [community wiki](https://signum.community/signum-mining/)

tags.name: admin
tags.description: Administrative operations which requires an API Key to be configured in the node.</br>🔓 __Security Advice: Use a very strong and truly random key, or even disable admin operation entirely in your node config. Exposing admin operations is a security risk.__
